publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-547# Mr Kenneth Gibson: Children in Glasgow Selling Newspapers Late at Night—That the Parliament notes with concern the illegal employment of children under sixteen years to sell newspapers in the streets of Glasgow, at city road junctions, outside pubs and clubs late at night and in the early hours of the morning in all weathers, to the detriment of their health and education and leaving them exposed to the possible attention of individuals with evil intent, and believes that the newspaper publishers concerned should ensure that their distributors do not employ vendors who recruit children, that the public should not buy these newspapers and that Strathclyde Police should vigorously enforce the law in this regard.
S1M-547# Children in Glasgow Selling Newspapers Late at Night (lodged on 15 February 2000) Brian Adam*

S1M-547# Mr Kenneth Gibson: Children in Glasgow Selling Newspapers Late at Night—That the Parliament notes with concern the illegal employment of children under sixteen years to sell newspapers in the streets of Glasgow, at city road junctions, outside pubs and clubs late at night and in the early hours of the morning in all weathers, to the detriment of their health and education and leaving them exposed to the possible attention of individuals with evil intent, and believes that the newspaper publishers concerned should ensure that their distributors do not employ vendors who recruit children, that the public should not buy these newspapers and that Strathclyde Police should vigorously enforce the law in this regard. Supported by: Brian Adam
S1M-547# Children in Glasgow Selling Newspapers Late at Night (lodged on 15 February 2000) Andrew Wilson*
S1M-547# Children in Glasgow Selling Newspapers Late at Night (lodged on 15 February 2000) Mr Gil Paterson*, Mr Adam Ingram*, Mr Kenny MacAskill*, Ms Sandra White*

S1M-547# Mr Kenneth Gibson: Children in Glasgow Selling Newspapers Late at Night—That the Parliament notes with concern the illegal employment of children under sixteen years to sell newspapers in the streets of Glasgow, at city road junctions, outside pubs and clubs late at night and in the early hours of the morning in all weathers, to the detriment of their health and education and leaving them exposed to the possible attention of individuals with evil intent, and believes that the newspaper publishers concerned should ensure that their distributors do not employ vendors who recruit children, that the public should not buy these newspapers and that Strathclyde Police should vigorously enforce the law in this regard. Supported by: Brian Adam, Andrew Wilson, Mr Gil Paterson, Mr Adam Ingram, Mr Kenny MacAskill, Ms Sandra White
S1M-547# Children in Glasgow Selling Newspapers Late at Night (lodged on 15 February 2000) Alex Neil*, Mr Brian Monteith*, Michael Russell*, Fiona McLeod*, Donald Gorrie*

S1M-547# Mr Kenneth Gibson: Children in Glasgow Selling Newspapers Late at Night—That the Parliament notes with concern the illegal employment of children under sixteen years to sell newspapers in the streets of Glasgow, at city road junctions, outside pubs and clubs late at night and in the early hours of the morning in all weathers, to the detriment of their health and education and leaving them exposed to the possible attention of individuals with evil intent, and believes that the newspaper publishers concerned should ensure that their distributors do not employ vendors who recruit children, that the public should not buy these newspapers and that Strathclyde Police should vigorously enforce the law in this regard. Supported by: Brian Adam, Andrew Wilson, Mr Gil Paterson, Mr Adam Ingram, Mr Kenny MacAskill, Ms Sandra White, Alex Neil, Mr Brian Monteith, Michael Russell, Fiona McLeod, Donald Gorrie, Irene McGugan, Richard Lochhead

S1M-547# Mr Kenneth Gibson: Children in Glasgow Selling Newspapers Late at Night—That the Parliament notes with concern the illegal employment of children under sixteen years to sell newspapers in the streets of Glasgow, at city road junctions, outside pubs and clubs late at night and in the early hours of the morning in all weathers, to the detriment of their health and education and leaving them exposed to the possible attention of individuals with evil intent, and believes that the newspaper publishers concerned should ensure that their distributors do not employ vendors who recruit children, that the public should not buy these newspapers and that Strathclyde Police should vigorously enforce the law in this regard.
